text: mity is simply another way of measuring
the concentration of a solution the
symbol for mality is lowercase letter M
and the formula is moles of solute over
kilog of solvent now let's do an example
using
mity the question tells us that we have
90 G of glucose and 200 g of H2O and
we're want to find the mity of the
solution so we basically taking glucose
the solute and water the solvent we're
mixing it and we want to find the
concentration in terms of molality the
first step is to find the molecular
weight of glucose this will help us find
the number of moles of glucose within
our solution the first step is to find
the atomic weight of each atom and
multiply it by each subscript so the
atomic weight of carbon is 12 G per mole
the atomic weight of H is 1 G per mole
and the atomic weight of oxygen is 16 G
per mole so we multiply 6 by 12 add that
to 12 * 1 and add that to 6 * 16 and we
get approximately 180 g per mole
Now using this number we can take our 90
G of glucose and find the number of
moles 90 G of glucose divided by 180 g
of glucose per
mole gets us5 or 1 12 moles of glucose
that's our number of moles within this
solution the final step is to use the
formula for for
mality lowercase M for mality is equal
to 12 number of moles of solute divided
by now notice we're given 200 g and mity
that unital mality are moles per
kilogram so we have to convert 200 g to
kilogram we get2 kgam of H2O to solvent
and we get 2.5
mity or moles per kilogram and that's
our final answer
